title: Sydney Sweeney Says Wrapping â€˜Euphoriaâ€™ Season 3 Will Be â€˜Bittersweetâ€™ and â€˜Emotionalâ€™: â€˜Itâ€™s Been My Entire Twentiesâ€™
description:
Sydney Sweeney is bracing herself for how emotional it will be to finish filming â€œEuphoriaâ€ Season 3.  

	The Cassie Howard actress was honored Wedn
body:
Sydney Sweeney is bracing herself for how emotional it will be to finish filming â€œEuphoriaâ€ Season 3.  

	The Cassie Howard actress was honored Wednesday night at Varietyâ€™s 2025 Power of Women ceremony in L.A. as one of the cover stars. She shares that sheâ€™s going back for her last two days of shooting â€œEuphoriaâ€ Season 3 on Thursday and Sunday.

	â€œItâ€™s gonna be a really bittersweet moment,â€ Sweeney told Varietyâ€™s Angelique Jackson about wrapping the season on the Power of Women red carpet. â€œIâ€™m kind of terrified for how emotional itâ€™s gonna be. Itâ€™s been such a journey. Itâ€™s been my entire twenties. Theyâ€™ve been my family and friends for so long. Iâ€™ve been forever grateful for all of them.â€
	

	Sweeney, now 28, told Varietyâ€™s Marc Malkin this week that â€œI was 20 when I did the pilot, so being able to see a lot of the same people, it feels very comforting.â€

	Not much is known about Season 3, other than it will release in spring 2026 and feature lots of returning cast members and new faces, like Trisha Paytas, Natasha Lyonne, Danielle Deadwyler and Eli Roth.

	Sweeneyâ€™s co-star Jacob Elordi said that â€œEuphoriaâ€ creator Sam Levinson â€œconstructed something thatâ€™s incredibly clever and cinematic.â€ 

	â€œIt was incredibly liberating,â€ Elordi said. â€œI got to play something so sort of far out from what Iâ€™ve done before.â€

	Next up, Sweeney is starring in the boxing biopic â€œChristyâ€ as real-life champion Christy Martin, who accompanied her to Power of Women. Sheâ€™s also starring in and executive producing a â€œBarbarellaâ€ remake for Sony. Jane Fonda, who starred in the original 1968 sci-fi movie, also attended Power of Women on Wednesday. Sweeney said on the red carpet that she wanted to pick Fondaâ€™s brain for her remake.
	

	â€œIf you see us in a corner the entire time, just know Iâ€™m asking absolutely everything,â€ she said.

schema.headline: Sydney Sweeney Says Wrapping â€˜Euphoriaâ€™ Season 3 Will Be â€˜Bittersweetâ€™ and â€˜Emotionalâ€™: â€˜Itâ€™s Been My Entire Twentiesâ€™

title: Ramsey Naito Exiting as Paramount Animationâ€™s  President (EXCLUSIVE)
description:
Ramsey Naito is exiting her post as president of Paramount Animation.

	â€œI want toÂ shareÂ with you that I am leaving theÂ company and closing this ver
body:
Ramsey Naito is exiting her post as president of Paramount Animation.

	â€œI want toÂ shareÂ with you that I am leaving theÂ company and closing this very special chapter with all of you,â€ she wrote on Wednesday night in a note to staff. â€œLeading this incredible team of talented storytellers, artists and dreamers, and watching the magic thatÂ youâ€™veÂ spun from your imagination and dedication, has been one of the great joys of my career.â€
	

	Her departure follows the studioâ€™s recent merger with Skydance, which has resulted in several significant executive shuffles. David Ellison, the companyâ€™s new chairman and CEO, announced heâ€™s undertaking a series of staffing cuts that are expected to eliminate approximately 2,000 jobs in the U.S. with additional layoffs taking place internationally.


	â€œWe want to be as open and direct as possible about the reasons behind these changes,â€ Ellison wrote in memo earlier in the day about the companywide cuts. â€œIn some areas, we are addressing redundancies that have emerged across the organization. In others, we are phasing out roles that are no longer aligned with our evolving priorities and the new structure designed to strengthen our focus on growth. Ultimately, these steps are necessary to position Paramount for long-term success.â€

	An Oscar-nominated producer of 2017â€™s â€œBoss Baby,â€ Naito started her career at Nickelodeon and returned in 2018 before she was promoted to president of the animation division in 2021. Since then, Naito was responsible for breathing new life into broadly appealing franchises at the film studio such as â€œSmurfs,â€ â€œTransformers,â€ â€œPAW Patrol,â€ â€œTeenage Mutant Ninja Turtlesâ€ and â€œSpongeBob SquarePants.â€ 
	

	In her previous role overseeing Nickelodeon Animation, Naito led animated content across all formats and platforms, spanning linear, digital, TV movies, theatrical motion pictures. This included the day-to-day operations of Nickelodeonâ€™s franchises, including â€œSpongeBob SquarePantsâ€ and its spinoffs like â€œThe Patrick Star Showâ€ and â€œKamp Koralâ€ as well as a new â€œDora the Explorerâ€ series.

	â€œI am soÂ proudÂ of the work the animation teams and I have done for the last 8+ years. I am honored to have given new life and love to the beloved characters and stories within the vast Paramount and Nickelodeon libraries â€” fromÂ â€˜SpongeBobâ€™Â toÂ â€˜PAW Patrolâ€™Â toÂ â€˜Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtlesâ€™ â€” and the birth of a whole new slate of originals for todayâ€™s generation,â€ Naitoâ€™s note continued. â€œNot only am I endlessly proud of what weâ€™ve built, but even more so the spirit behind it â€” the collaboration, creativity, and kindness that define this team. Though Iâ€™m moving on, Iâ€™ll always be cheering you on (and singing along to theÂ â€˜PAW Patrolâ€™Â theme or humming theÂ â€˜TMNTâ€™Â riff when I see your work lighting up screens everywhere).â€

	She concluded, â€œThankÂ youÂ to Josh, Dana and the fantastic leadership team who I know will keep propelling our animation business to great heights.â€

	Sheâ€™s referring to Paramount Pictures co-chairs Dana Goldberg and Josh Greenstein, who called Naito an â€œincredible partner and leader.â€

	â€œWeâ€™re so appreciative of Ramseyâ€™s creativity, dedication, and lasting influence on our animation slate,â€  Goldberg and Greenstein said in a statement. â€œSheâ€™s been an incredible partner and leader, and her work has left a lasting mark on our studio as we look toward the future.â€

schema.headline: Ramsey Naito Exiting as Paramount Animationâ€™s  President (EXCLUSIVE)

title: Sharon Stone Defends Sydney Sweeney After Jeans Ad Controversy: â€˜Itâ€™s Okay to Use What Your Mama Gave Youâ€™
description: Sharon Stone was on hand for Varietyâ€™s Power of Women LA event on Wednesday, set to present honors to Sydney Sweeney as one of the eveningâ€™s honoree
body:
Sharon Stone was on hand for Varietyâ€™s Power of Women LA event on Wednesday, set to present honors to Sydney Sweeney as one of the eveningâ€™s honorees. The two actresses have been working on â€œEuphoriaâ€ Season 3 for several months now, including after Sweeney faced controversy for featuring in an American Eagle ad campaign in July. The commercials centered on the slogan â€œSydney Sweeney Has Great Jeans,â€Â a pun on â€œgreat genesâ€; it drew backlash from critics who alleged the ads glorified Sweeneyâ€™s white heritage and physique.
	

	â€œItâ€™s okay to use what mama gave you. Itâ€™s really fine,â€ Stone told Variety senior entertainment writer Angelique Jackson on the carpet, voicing her support for Sweeney. â€œItâ€™s hard to be hot, and I think we all know that. Itâ€™s really okay to use every bit of hotness you have â€” right here, right now â€” and go for whatever that is. Everybody has their own certain kind of hotness, their own certain thing, and youâ€™re supposed to go for that. Because who are you not to be beautiful? You know, who you are isnâ€™t an accident.â€

	Stone recounted a conversation that she had with Sweeney as the â€œgreat jeansâ€ controversy was taking hold, as the two actresses continued production on â€œEuphoria.â€

	â€œBecause I was co-godparents with Jane Goodall, I said, â€˜When Jane was on the cover of Life Magazine for her work with gorillas, she was in her safari shorts and shirt, sitting with one of the animals that she was working with. Other scientists said, â€˜Well, she only got the cover of Life Magazine because she had good legs.â€™ And Jane said, â€˜Well, if I did, then that helped me get more money for my research,'â€ Stone said. â€œSydney said, â€˜Yeah, and Iâ€™m sure I made a billion dollars for the jeans company, and Iâ€™m good with that. Because, you know what? Iâ€™ll get another job.'â€
	

	Stone is a new addition to the ensemble for â€œEuphoriaâ€ Season 3, which will reportedly take place after a years-long time jump following the events of Season 2. Sweeney is reprising her role from the first two seasons, as are stars Zendaya, Jacob Elordi, Eric Dane, Alexa Demie, Maude Apatow, Colman Domingo and others. While Stone may be a series newcomer, she says sheâ€™s been a longtime â€œEuphoriaâ€ fan. 

	â€œI had to watch it for the 67th time to get caught up again,â€ Stone joked. â€œIt was such a joy to go to work with these amazing young people.â€

	Director Paul Feig, who worked with Sweeney on her upcoming thriller â€œThe Housemaid,â€ also offered his support for his star in her Power of Women Variety cover story, calling the â€œgreat jeansâ€ controversy â€œmanufacturedâ€ by â€œa certain segment of the media [who] blew it up.â€

	â€œSheâ€™s probably one of the most confident people Iâ€™ve ever met in my life â€” in a good way. Sheâ€™s very savvy,â€ Feig said.

	Along with Sweeney, Varietyâ€™s Power of Women L.A. event on Wednesday honored Wanda Sykes, Jamie Lee Curtis, Nicole Scherzinger and Kate Hudson.

schema.headline: Sharon Stone Defends Sydney Sweeney After Jeans Ad Controversy: â€˜Itâ€™s Okay to Use What Your Mama Gave Youâ€™

title: â€˜Hello Kittyâ€™ Movie Sets July 2028 Release Date From Warner Bros.
description: After several years in development, Warner Bros. Pictures Animation and New Line Cinema are finally moving ahead with the â€œHello Kittyâ€ feature film
body:
After several years in development, Warner Bros. Pictures Animation and New Line Cinema are finally moving ahead with the â€œHello Kittyâ€ feature film, dating it for July 21, 2028.

	â€œHello Hollywood ğŸ€ğŸŒ´ğŸ¬â€¨#HelloKittyMovie is coming to theaters July 21, 2028!,â€ said an Instagram post from the studio on Wednesday.

	â€œThe film marks Hello Kittyâ€™s HollywoodÂ theatrical debut as Hello Kitty and her friends embark on a cinematic adventure sure to delight audiences of all ages,â€ the studio said in a statement.
	

	Leo Matsuda is directing, while Dana Fox (â€œWickedâ€) wrote the most recent draft of the script. Matsuda directed the short â€œInner Workingsâ€ and worked as a story artist on films including â€œZootopiaâ€ and â€œWreck-It Ralph.â€

	Producer Beau Flynn of FlynnPictureCo., spent nearly a decade working with Sanrio founder Shintaro Tsuji to get rights to the character. Shelby Thomas will oversee for FlynnPictureCo.

	Japanâ€™s Sanrio first introduced the adorable big-headed feline in 1974 and quickly unleashed a merchandising juggernaut, with entire stores devoted to thousands of items branded with Hello Kitty and her friends, such as Dear Daniel and superhero alter ego Ichigoman. Thereâ€™s a Hello Kitty theme park in Japan, Hello Kitty cafÃ©s, dozens of video games and numerous collaborations for high-end clothing and other adult-targeted products.

	The English-language feature project was first announced by New Line in 2019, and was the first time Sanrio had licensed film rights to the classic cat. Itâ€™s not yet known whether Kitty White (yes, she has a last name) will speak in the film, but lacking a mouth, she has been completely silent to date in several animated series about her adventures. Sanrio also licensed rights to other characters, including the cracked egg character Gudetama, the rabbit character My Melody, and Little Twin Stars, so it wouldnâ€™t be surprising to see them play in the same sandbox as Hello Kitty.
	

	Matsuda is repped by Verve and manager Stacey Lublinerâ€™s SEL media company.

schema.headline: â€˜Hello Kittyâ€™ Movie Sets July 2028 Release Date From Warner Bros.

title: Australian Horror â€˜Nightfall: A Paranormal Investigationâ€™ Acquired by Black Mandala (EXCLUSIVE)
description: New Zealand-based sales outfit Black Mandala has acquired â€œNightfall: A Paranormal Investigation,â€ an Australian horror film directed by Myles McEwe
body:
New Zealand-based sales outfit Black Mandala has acquired â€œNightfall: A Paranormal Investigation,â€ an Australian horror film directed by Myles McEwen and Ripley Stevens, with the production-sales company eyeing franchise potential, it was revealed on the sidelines of TIFFCOM, the Tokyo International Film Festivalâ€˜s market arm. 

	Set in 1988, the paranormal thriller follows investigators Mick Sutherland and Archie Charlesworth as they respond to a desperate call from Elizabeth Blairâ€™s isolated home, where they encounter a malevolent presence that unravels their sanity over seven days in what becomes known as Case 13.
	

	The Adelaide-based filmmaking duo wrote, directed and star in the feature. The film pays homage to classics like â€œThe Exorcistâ€ while offering a fresh take on the paranormal-investigation subgenre.


	McEwen revealed the project was inspired by unsettling personal experiences. â€œThe film was inspired by a series of haunting events â€” I watched my co-star Ripley sleepwalk and speak for an entire week in a deceased manâ€™s apartment in Budapest, whilst back in Adelaide, I was told my bedroom light switched on by itself several times,â€ he said. â€œIt felt as though something spiritual â€” maybe even demonic â€” was haunting us.â€

	â€œNightfallâ€ has drawn comparisons to James Wan and Leigh Whannellâ€™s work, positioning McEwen and Stevens as part of a new wave of Australian horror filmmakers.

	Black Mandala confirmed ongoing collaborations with McEwen and Stevens following the acquisition. The company recently boarded â€œHollywood Hells,â€ a thriller that takes aim at the entertainment industryâ€™s dark side. 
	

	Michael Kraetzer and Nicolas Onetti launched Black Mandala in 2017, building it into a leading player in independent horror and genre distribution. Operating from Auckland, New Zealand, the outfit handles north of 100 titles and maintains a presence at major markets, championing visually striking material and cultivating ongoing relationships with genre filmmakers globally.

schema.headline: Australian Horror â€˜Nightfall: A Paranormal Investigationâ€™ Acquired by Black Mandala (EXCLUSIVE)

title: YouTube, as Part of AI-Focused Reorganization, Is Offering Employees Voluntarily Exit Packages With Severance
description: AI is â€œthe next frontierâ€ for YouTube, according to CEO Neal Mohan â€” and it might result in the video platformâ€™s shrinking its employee headcount.
body:
AI is â€œthe next frontierâ€ for YouTube, according to CEO Neal Mohan â€” and it might result in the video platformâ€™s shrinking its employee headcount.

	Mohan, in a memo Wednesday to YouTube staffers, announced a major reorg of its product team into three groups: Subscriptions Products (headed by Christian Oestlien), Viewer Products (led by Johanna Voolich, formerly YouTubeâ€™s chief product officer), and Creator & Community Products (with a lead yet to be hired).
	

	According to Mohan, the moves are related to positioning YouTube for an AI-centric future. â€œLooking to the future, the next frontier for YouTube is AI, which has the potential to transform every part of the platform,â€ Mohan said in an internal memo, as first reported by Alex Heathâ€™s Sources AI newsletter. â€œWe need to set ourselves up to make the most of this opportunity.â€


	As part of the shift to AI, YouTube is introducing a â€œvoluntary exit programâ€ for employees, per Mohanâ€™s memo.

	A YouTube rep, asked for more info, confirmed that YouTube is offering a voluntary exit program with severance for U.S.-based employees who may want to leave the company. However, currently, there are no role eliminations or layoffs happening as part of these changes, the spokesperson said.

	Other big tech companies are already cutting jobs in anticipation of massive changes introduced by AI. On Tuesday, AmazonÂ said it will cut about 14,000 corporate jobs, representing about 4% of the total corporate workforce, citing rapid developments in AI; more cuts are expected by the ecommerce giant in 2026.
	

	Mohanâ€™s AI-driven reorg memo came prior to parent company Alphabet reporting Q3 earnings. YouTube ad revenue for the period was $10.26 billion, a year-over-year increase of 15%, beating Wall Street analyst forecasts.

schema.headline: YouTube, as Part of AI-Focused Reorganization, Is Offering Employees Voluntarily Exit Packages With Severance

title: â€˜Alien: Earthâ€™ Exec Touts Thailandâ€™s 30% Film Incentive, Asia Hub Status at Tokyo Fest
description: Thailand has transformed from a scenic backdrop into one of Asiaâ€™s most competitive production hubs, backed by enhanced film incentives and robust i
body:
Thailand has transformed from a scenic backdrop into one of Asiaâ€™s most competitive production hubs, backed by enhanced film incentives and robust infrastructure, according to unit production manager Apinat Obb Siricharoenjit, who presented at the MPA seminar at the Tokyo International Film Festival.

	Speaking at the event, the â€œAlien: Earthâ€ production manager detailed Thailandâ€™s journey from hosting location shoots to becoming a full-service production destination trusted by studios and filmmakers worldwide. The country has successfully increased its film incentive to 30% on local spend without any cap, up from the initial 15% when first introduced in 2017, with an uplift to 20% before the recent increase at the end of last year.
	

	â€œWhat you just saw is actually evidence that Thailand is no longer just a backdrop of any film. Itâ€™s rather now developed into one of Asiaâ€™s most competitive production hub trusted by studios and filmmakers all over the world,â€ Siricharoenjit said, following a video showcase of films produced in the country.


	The production manager, whose company Living Films has put at least 15 films through Thailandâ€™s incentive program and was among the first to utilize it, emphasized that the countryâ€™s appeal extends beyond financial incentives. â€œItâ€™s also the infrastructure, the crew and the creativity of the local people,â€ he explained.

	Thailandâ€™s success stems from collaboration between government agencies and the private sector. The Ministry of Cultureâ€™s Department of Cultural Development and the Department of Tourism work alongside Thailandâ€™s film office and private companies, with industry professionals sitting on advisory boards to guide policy development. â€œOur government recognizes that film is not just art. It is an industry and a bridge to soft power,â€ Siricharoenjit noted, adding that stable government policies and competitive incentives have been crucial to attracting international productions.
	

	The scale of production activity has created substantial economic impact. â€œAlien: Earthâ€ alone generated 24,000 jobs across the country, with 1,600 local crew members on weekly payroll and a construction crew of 450 people. The production bought out hotels in Krabi in southern Thailand and chartered planes for the shoot.

	Siricharoenjit emphasized the importance of crew pipeline development, noting that local departments have grown from small units to global-scale teams. â€œCrew became bilingual, trained by working side by side with the best people in Hollywood, Europe, Korea, Japan,â€ he said. However, he acknowledged challenges when multiple major productions overlap. During â€œAlien: Earthâ€ production, at least 70% of Thailandâ€™s crew base was employed, and the situation became more strained when â€œJurassic Worldâ€ arrived, bringing 400 crew members to service their shoot and competing for locations.

	â€œAlien: Earthâ€ presented unique challenges that expanded Thailandâ€™s capabilities. â€œThere are departments and sections that we never done in Thailand before, like, for example, we never had a creature department,â€ Siricharoenjit revealed, explaining how collaboration with international teams helped develop new skills. The elaborate creature eggs featured in the production were crafted by Thai artisans.

	Film production continues to drive tourism long after cameras stop rolling. Maya Bay, featured in â€œThe Beachâ€ (2000) starring Leonardo DiCaprio, remains a popular destination despite being â€œjust only a small bay. Actually. Itâ€™s really tiny.â€ The Lebua hotel, which featured in â€œThe Hangover Part IIâ€ (2011), still offers a Hangover Suite as one of its best-selling accommodations and serves a Hangover cocktail among its top sellers. More recently, â€œWhite Lotusâ€ shot at a property in Koh Samui saw occupancy rates surge after the first two episodes aired, demonstrating â€œthe economic impact of international films.â€

	The influx of international productions has catalyzed infrastructure development. â€œThe ecosystem starts, and itâ€™s followed with all the vendors, sound stages, rental houses, equipment, base. Itâ€™s all growing because of all these international productions that came in, and thatâ€™s the demand for it,â€ Siricharoenjit explained. 

	The combination of global expertise and local craftsmanship distinguishes Thailandâ€™s offerings. â€œArt directors with infused local textures, costume teams that understand fabric traditions, crafts people, construction team who built sets. This mix of global skills and local artistry is what makes Thailand truly different,â€ he said. â€œEvery production leaves more than images on the screen, and film is more than production. It is identity, influence and memory.â€
	

	To maintain its super hub status, Siricharoenjit stressed the need for continued evolution. â€œWe must keep incentives competitive and predictable. Speed of approval, transparency of audit, and you must keep improving on the incentive,â€ he said, adding that the country must continue connecting film to culture. â€œWe must continue trying film to culture, not just action films in Bangkok or epics in jungles, but dramas in historic towns, stories that showcase our creative cities, our crowds and our music. A super hub is not only a service platform, it is also a cultural part.â€

schema.headline: â€˜Alien: Earthâ€™ Exec Touts Thailandâ€™s 30% Film Incentive, Asia Hub Status at Tokyo Fest

title: â€˜Kokuhoâ€™ Team on Bringing Kabuki Theater to a Younger Generation: â€˜Itâ€™s a Movie About Art, Two Actors and the Life of Actorsâ€™
description: As part of Varietyâ€™s Screening Series, â€œKokuhoâ€ production designer Yohei Taneda and producer Chieko Murata joined Varietyâ€™s co-editor-in-chief Cynt
body:
As part of Varietyâ€™s Screening Series, â€œKokuhoâ€ production designer Yohei Taneda and producer Chieko Murata joined Varietyâ€™s co-editor-in-chief Cynthia Littleton for a candid conversation about the making of the Japanese drama on Oct. 26 in Los Angeles.

	Murata kicked off the conversation explaining what Kabuki theater offers Japanese audiences by having it as the filmâ€™s backdrop and discussed their desire to center a story about a young boy who, after his fatherâ€™s death, develops into a gifted performer after being adopted by a famous Kabuki actor.Â 
	

	â€œFor Japanese people, especially the younger audience, and a regular U.S. audience, itâ€™s similar,â€ Murata began. â€œThey have never seen Kabuki and donâ€™t know that much about it. Itâ€™s a discovery. Also, they donâ€™t think of it as a movie about Kabuki. Itâ€™s a movie about art, two actors and the life of actors.â€

	Taneda touched on the challenges of recreating the different periods of Japanese culture presented throughout the film, in addition to showcasing the elaborate Kabuki styles. 

	One of the biggest obstacles that Taneda faced was having to build a Kabuki stage from scratch on a sound stage for the last quarter of the film.

	â€œWe were very cognizant of being able to use what we see as is,â€ Taneda said. â€œGenerally, with my approach, all the different sets have elements about them that would be slightly different from a real Kabuki stage. One of the challenges is that you cannot rent a Kabuki stage or theater in Japan that actually exists.â€

	Murata, who joined as the filmâ€™s producer about five years ago, said she resonated with the filmâ€™s themes of life, sacrifice and loneliness. â€œItâ€™s this complex pressure and life of an artist that no other people can understand,â€ she said. â€œA lot of people could resonate with that. Thatâ€™s universal.â€Â 
	

	â€œKokuhoâ€ stars Ryo Yoshizawa, Ryusei Yokohama and Ken Watanabe. As the conversation ended, Taneda and Murata praised the cast for their performances. Murata said she was inspired by Watanabeâ€™s focus and determination to tell the story while on set.Â 

	Taneda admired Yokohama and Yoshizawaâ€™s ability to bring depth and complexity to their characters while also introducing Kabuki to a new generation.

	â€œThey were able to be interpreters of Kabuki to the current generation,â€ he said. â€œThrough their friendship and lives, Kabuki all of a sudden became very accessible to this new younger crowd.â€

schema.headline: â€˜Kokuhoâ€™ Team on Bringing Kabuki Theater to a Younger Generation: â€˜Itâ€™s a Movie About Art, Two Actors and the Life of Actorsâ€™

title: â€˜Crouching Tigerâ€™ Oscar Winner Tim Yip Champions Human Touch in Artificial Intelligence Filmmaking at Kling AI Tokyo Awards
description: In a Tokyo screening room filled with filmmakers and creators from around the world, Oscar-winning art director Tim Yip delivered a clarion call for
body:
In a Tokyo screening room filled with filmmakers and creators from around the world, Oscar-winning art director Tim Yip delivered a clarion call for preserving human emotion in an age of artificial intelligence. 

	â€œTechnology is so strong, you have to get something more than, higher than the technology to make it as a tool, so not as a god,â€ Yip said during the KlingAI NextGen Creative Contest awards ceremony and panel discussion.


	The event, held alongside the Tokyo International Film Festival, showcased winning films from a competition that attracted more than 4,600 submissions from 122 countries and regions, competing for a $42,000 prize pool. But rather than celebrating technical prowess alone, the eveningâ€™s most powerful moments centered on deeply personal stories of memory, humanity and the creative partnership between humans and machines.
	

	Zeng Yushen, representing Kling AI, set the tone for the evening by framing the contest as more than mere competition. â€œTonight isnâ€™t just about awards, itâ€™s about celebrating creators and all the stories they bring to life,â€ he said. â€œAt Kling AI, we always want to empower creators to give them tools to expand their creative freedom, as well as to give them new tools to do very new storytelling.â€

	Yip, who won the Academy Award for art direction for â€œCrouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,â€ praised the grand prize winner â€œAlzheimerâ€ for its exploration of memory loss. The film, created by Chinese student CÂ·one and inspired by a team memberâ€™s relative suffering from the disease, uses an oil painting aesthetic to depict the inner world of someone experiencing cognitive decline.
	

	â€œWhen you are young, the energies come from you, so that you always have a new energy to build up new ideas,â€ Yip reflected. â€œBut at the end, you are leaving your body, your spirit, and living more and more. So I feel this is really important, no matter AI film or some modern film, or the classical film â€” they always talk about humans and the relationship with the world and the environment too.â€

	South Korean director Lee Hwan-kyung, whose 2013 film â€œMiracle in Cell No. 7â€ became a box office phenomenon, echoed the emphasis on emotional authenticity. â€œI think itâ€™s better to think about how we can collaborate together with AI so that we can bring this human emotion to the movies,â€ Lee said, drawing laughter when he joked: â€œIâ€™m just personally hoping that the AI technology really slowly develops.â€

	The winning creators themselves spoke about how AI tools enabled them to realize deeply personal visions that would have been impossible through traditional filmmaking. Leammonn, a South Korean media artist and adjunct professor who won an official selection award for â€œIâ€™m Not a Robot,â€ envisioned AIâ€™s potential to create new forms of storytelling. â€œI imagine the future of the interactive film,â€ she said. â€œIf we are making some kind of playground, using the things with technology or with some kind of network, it will be very powerful.â€

	Polish filmmaker and motion designer Dawid Meller, whose â€œLost & Foundâ€ also received an official selection, described AI as liberating. â€œI was collecting a lot of ideas, and there are many limits when youâ€™re creating films and stories â€” you are limited by budget and technology and sometimes bad time of your collaborators,â€ he said. â€œBut with AI, I could finally free myself and do a lot of these kind of things alone.â€

	CÂ·one, the grand prize winner, described the creative process behind â€œAlzheimer.â€ â€œWhen I use this AI tool, I just take the clean AI as the first step, like my camera,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s a process for me to start to organize this story and to do real thinking about this storytelling.â€

	Yip shared his own experimental journey with AI, describing how he created an alien character searching for human ruins in empty space. â€œI talked to him, and he changed. He will react to me,â€ Yip said of the AI tool. â€œEvery time Iâ€™m not asking him to do what kind of things, but I am just asking him questions, and then they come up with all these reactions. So that I follow the reaction, and I come more deeper and deeper.â€
	

	The evening highlighted both the possibilities and anxieties surrounding AI in filmmaking. Yip warned against the medium becoming too focused on spectacle. â€œI worry about when we are still only working on the exciting moments, maybe after five years, no people have the really strong reaction of all that,â€ he said. â€œThe most important thing is to going back to reality, try to repeat, try to create. But I think AI is really for me, itâ€™s very exciting because I try to push it in some human touch, really sensible human touch.

	Yet the panelâ€™s overarching message was one of collaboration rather than competition. Lee suggested AI could help bridge the traditional conflict between screenwriters and directors by enabling rapid visualization of scenarios. â€œI believe that thereâ€™s a chance that we can actually integrate the one point between the script writer and the person who tries to direct it,â€ he said.

	Meller provided a concrete example of AIâ€™s democratizing potential, describing how a scene that would have cost half his filmâ€™s budget and taken weeks with traditional effects was roughed out in five minutes using Kling AI. â€œNow, like, not only big Hollywood studios could afford to make really high quality productions,â€ he said. â€œEveryone, even smaller teams or single creators can can actually do it.â€

	The event was hosted by Kling AI, a platform that has surpassed 45 million users globally and reached an annualized revenue run rate exceeding $100 million within 10 months of launch. The NextGen Creative Contest offered a $42,000 prize pool, with China, the U.S., and India leading in submissions.

	As the evening concluded, CÂ·one announced plans to create a new AI film about his hometown region grasslands, while exploring how to better integrate AI with traditional storytelling techniques. Leammonn expressed interest in developing interactive films that could help combat social isolation, while Meller revealed heâ€™s working on both a traditional sci-fi comedy and a fully animated AI series.

	Perhaps the most memorable insight came from Yip when asked what advice heâ€™d give emerging AI creators. â€œI think you can do anything,â€ he said simply, before describing the creative process as moving â€œfrom outside to inside.â€

	The panel was moderated by Hanqing, founder of AI Talk. 
	

	In an era of rapid technological change, the Tokyo gathering suggested that the future of filmmaking may depend less on choosing between human and artificial intelligence, and more on their thoughtful synthesis â€” with human emotion firmly in the driverâ€™s seat.

schema.headline: â€˜Crouching Tigerâ€™ Oscar Winner Tim Yip Champions Human Touch in Artificial Intelligence Filmmaking at Kling AI Tokyo Awards

title: Disney and YouTube Settle Lawsuit Over Poaching of Exec Justin Connolly
description: Disney has settled its differences with YouTube over the departure of Justin Connolly, a high-level exec who now oversees YouTubeâ€™s media and sports
body:
Disney has settled its differences with YouTube over the departure of Justin Connolly, a high-level exec who now oversees YouTubeâ€™s media and sports operations.

	Connolly left Disney in May after 25 years at the company. Disney immediately sued YouTube for poaching him, and sued Connolly for breaching his contract. According to the suit, Connolly was just five months into a new three-year contract as president of platform distribution.
	

	Disneyâ€™s lawyers filed a notice of settlement on Tuesday, which did not reveal any details of the resolution.


	Connolly was paid $6 million in 2024, making him one of Disneyâ€™s highest paid executives. He oversaw a team of 300 people who were responsible for content distribution deals with cable and satellite providers, streaming services and YouTube TV. He reported to Jimmy Pitaro, Dana Walden and Alan Bergman, who in turn report to Disney CEO Bob Iger.

	According to Disney, Connollyâ€™s defection came at a critical time, as the company was beginning its billion-dollar license renewal negotiations with YouTube â€” with Connolly as lead negotiator. Disney argued that Connolly was effectively switching sides, and would bring a wealth of inside knowledge about Disneyâ€™s strategy in those negotiations.

	(As of now, those talks appear to be at a standstill. Last week, Disney warned customers that its programming could be dropped from YouTube TV imminently if a deal is not reached.)

	Disney also feared that as YouTube enters into direct competition with ESPN for sports rights, Connolly would have inside information about ESPNâ€™s ability to pay â€” putting Disney at a competitive disadvantage.
	

	According to Connolly, he was personally warned by Iger and other top executives that Disney would seek to block him from moving to YouTube.

	YouTube argued in court that Connolly would be walled off from all negotiations with Disney, and would be required to adhere to his confidentiality obligations to Disney. YouTubeâ€™s lawyers also suggested that Disney was merely seeking to use its claim over Connollyâ€™s services as a chip in the license renewal talks â€” seeking to expedite those talks by offering to release Connollyâ€™s obligations once the talks were concluded. 

	YouTube also argued that Connollyâ€™s contract was effectively at-will, and not a fixed-term agreement, as Disney retained the right to terminate him at any time without necessarily paying out the remainder of his deal absent a release.

	In June, Judge James Chalfant denied Disneyâ€™s motion for a restraining order to block Connolly from working for YouTube. The judge found that Disney had not shown the requisite emergency and had not shown that it was likely to succeed on the merits.

	Connolly told the court that he was grateful for the opportunities he received at Disney, and â€œsaddened, though not terribly surprised, that Disney filed a lawsuit against me.â€

	â€œI desire nothing more than to pursue my dream job at YouTube,â€ he stated. â€œAnd I hope that, in time, Disney will move on from their disappointment over my departure and that I will be able to restore my relationships with so many Disney colleagues.â€

schema.headline: Disney and YouTube Settle Lawsuit Over Poaching of Exec Justin Connolly

title: "Fresh Prince of Bel Air" Child Actor Floyd Roger Myers Jr. Dead at 42
description:
'Fresh Prince of Bel Air' Child Star
                          Floyd Roger Myers Jr. Dead at 42
body:
'Fresh Prince of Bel Air' Child Star
                          Floyd Roger Myers Jr. Dead at 42
                      
                  
                        Published October 29, 2025 7:08 PM PDT
                                                                            
      
    
      
        
              
    
    
          Floyd Roger Myers Jr. -- a former child actor best known for his role in the "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" -- has died ... TMZ has learned.
      
    
          His mom, Renee Trice tells TMZ â€¦ Myers passed away in the wee hours of Wednesday morning from a heart attack at his home in Maryland. She tells us he suffered 3 prior heart attacks over the course of the last three years. She says she just spoke to her son last night.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Floyd kicked off his career as a younger version of Will Smith in the hit sitcom "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" ... before taking on the role as a young Marlon Jackson in the television miniseries "The Jacksons: An American Dream."
      
    
          Myers had bit part in one episode of the short-lived TV drama "Young Americans" in 2000.
      
    
          Floyd was 42.
      
    
          RIP
      
      
              
          
                          
                Fairly Legal

schema.headline: "Fresh Prince of Bel Air" Child Actor Floyd Roger Myers Jr. Dead at 42

title: Ex-Cop Who Killed Sonya Massey Over Boiling Water Found Guilty of Murder
description:
Sonya Massey
                          Former Deputy Guilty of Murder ...
body:
Sonya Massey
                          Former Deputy Guilty of Murder ...
                          Shot Woman Who Called 911
                      
                  
                        Published October 29, 2025 1:42 PM PDT
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Sonya Massey's killer has officially been found guilty of her murder ... a little more than a year after he shot and killed her.
      
    
          Sean Grayson -- a former sheriff's deputy in Illinois -- was just found guilty of second-degree murder after a trial that lasted a little more than a week. The jury began deliberations Tuesday morning and returned the verdict Wednesday afternoon.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Remember ... Grayson was arrested in July 2024 after he killed Massey, who had called 911 in the first place about a possible prowler. Horrific body cam footage came out in the aftermath of the shooting ... which showed the conversation take a deadly turn after Massey turned off a burner on her stove and brought a pot of boiling water over to the sink.
      

        
                    
                      7/6/24
                  
      
    
          With another deputy looking on, Grayson loses his cool and tells her repeatedly to drop the pot ... before stepping around the counter and shooting her. The Sangamon County Sheriff's Office later fired Grayson -- who claimed he feared Massey meant to throw the boiling water at him.
      
    
          Famed civil rights attorney Ben Crump -- who represented Sonya's family -- told us he and Sonya's father, James Wilburn, weren't buying Grayson's excuse after the body cam footage was released. The family has since secured a $10 million civil settlement connected to her death.
      
      
              
            
              Related articles
            
        
              
          
                          
                Fairly Legal
              
                          
                News

schema.headline: Ex-Cop Who Killed Sonya Massey Over Boiling Water Found Guilty of Murder

title: Producer Gets 146 Years for Drug Overdose Deaths of Model & Her Friend
description:
Hollywood Producer
                          146 Years in Prison
                          For Druggin
body:
Hollywood Producer
                          146 Years in Prison
                          For Drugging, Raping, Murdering Women
                      
                  
                        Published October 29, 2025 2:22 PM PDT
                                                                            
              
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Hollywood producer and serial rapist David Brian Pearce was sentenced to 146 years to life in prison Wednesday for the tragic drug overdose deaths of a model and her friend ... in addition to other heinous convictions.
      
    
          Pearce was convicted of murdering 24-year-old Christy Giles and her 26-year-old friend Hilda Marcela Cabrales-Arzola in the first degree back in February. According to ABC7 Los Angeles, further investigation also uncovered rapes he committed against several women over more than a decade -- he was also convicted of multiple counts including forcible rape, sexual penetration by use of force, rape of an unconscious person, and sodomy by use of force.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Prosecutors said Pearce reportedly met Giles and Cabrales-Arzola at an after-hours rave and later drugged them to facilitate a sexual assault.
      

          The details of Giles' and Cabrales-Arzola's last moments are disturbing. On November 13, 2021, Giles -- a model and aspiring actress -- was already dead when she was taken to Southern California Hospital at Culver City in the L.A. area, ABC7 reports.
      
    
          Cabrales-Arzola -- an architect -- was in critical condition when she arrived at Kaiser Permanente West Los Angeles Hospital. Her heartbroken family made the difficult decision to take her off life support later that month.
      
    
          Prosecutors told jurors Pearce and co-defendant Brandt Walter Osborn were the ones who dropped the women off at the respective hospitals 2 hours apart ... after they overdosed at the apartment the men shared.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Giles reportedly died of a lethal mix of cocaine, fentanyl, gamma-hydroxybutyric acid, and ketamine ... while Cabrales-Arzola died of multiple organ failure, with cocaine, ecstasy, and other undetermined drugs found in her system.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Pearce reportedly denied giving them the drugs that killed them, but after two and half days of deliberation, the jury decided they weren't buying it.
      
    
          Osborn, 46 -- who was facing 2 counts of being an accessory after the fact -- is awaiting a potential retrial after jurors said they were deadlocked over his verdict.
      
    
          Giles' mother, Dusty, reportedly said she was "so proud" of the prosecution for winning the case, and happy that Pearce's sexual assault victims "finally had their day in court" too.

schema.headline: Producer Gets 146 Years for Drug Overdose Deaths of Model & Her Friend

title: Yvette Nicole Brown Says Women Get Too Hung Up on 'Lists' While Dating
description:
Yvette Nicole Brown
                          Ladies, Check Your Friendzone Instead of Your 'List
body:
Yvette Nicole Brown
                          Ladies, Check Your Friendzone Instead of Your 'Lists'
                      
                  
                        Published October 29, 2025 3:08 PM PDT
                                                                            
      
    
      
        
                    
                  
      
                    TMZ.com
          
    
          Yvette Nicole Brown says young women should care about the size of a guy's heart instead of his bank account ... while encouraging them to revisit some of those dudes they may have written off as just friends.
      
    
          We caught up with the "Community" star at an event for Lifetime's "Love of a Lifetime" slate ... an upcoming series of films airing on the channel all about love -- including Toni Braxtonâ€™s "He Wasnâ€™t Man Enough," which stars Brown -- and we asked her about dating advice in today's modern world.
      
    
      
        
              
    
    
          Brown says she fears young people are too obsessed with checking boxes off their "lists" which are focused on surface-level traits -- money, height, for example -- instead of the stuff that really matters ... like kindness.
      

          Brown points to her husband, Anthony Davis, and mentions how he always has a cup of tea waiting for her when she wakes up ... a small act of kindness that clearly speaks volumes to YNB.
      
    
          Yvette says girls who are looking for something real might not need to look as far as they think either ... encouraging them to take another look at the guys they've friend-zoned!
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Worth noting ... Brown and Davis married just last year -- so, take a listen to all their comments if you wanna land a good one like they both did!
      
    
          Yvette's appearing in a movie titled "He Wasn't Man Enough" ... and it sounds like she wants people to dig deeper to figure out what "enough" really means!
      
      
              
          
                          
                Toni Braxton
              
                          
                Celebrity News
              
                          
                Dating
              
                          
                Exclusive
              
                          
                Fairly Legal
              
                          
                In The Field

schema.headline: Yvette Nicole Brown Says Women Get Too Hung Up on 'Lists' While Dating
